div.l: Marriage MM drafts toward Marriage throughout this page; Marriage first published in Manikin, Number 3 (NY: Monroe Wheeler, 1923). On this and many other pages, one cannot distinguish clearly which lines are drafted specifically toward Marriage. For theories as to whether MM is initially drafting one or two poems, see the Introduction to this notebook.lupin small blue flowers growing

Mt Rainier MM drafts toward An Octopus on this page; An Octopus, first published in The Dial 77 (December 1924). On this and many other pages, one cannot distinguish clearly which lines are drafted specifically toward An Octopus. Robert of Sorbonne de Sorbonne, Robert (1201-1274). A thirteenth-century scholar who urges serious students to engage in logical discussion since Nothing is perfectly known unless it has been tried by the tooth of disputation (as translated by James J. Walsh, Medieval Universities, The Rosary Magazine Volume 31 [July-December 1907] 78); Sorbonne established the Sorbonne University in Paris.with his habits

Mr Verdant Green A three-part popular novel by Cuthbert M. Bede (pseudonym of Edward Bradley, 1827-1889) was published in the 1850s under various titles, including The Adventures of Mr. Verdant Green. The character Green was a fictional undergraduate at Oxford University. disciple of Plato.

The gleaner (Mr. Ditmars Squirrel) MM drafts toward The Jerboa; some phrases appear in published poem. In her Note to the poem, MM writes There are little rats called jerboas which run on long hind-legs as thin as a match. The forelimbs are mere tiny hands. Dr. R. L. Ditmars, Strange Animals I Have Known (New York: Harcourt, Brace, 1931), p. 274.Ditmar, Raymond Lee (1876-1942). An American naturalist and author who founded the New York Zoological Society, which was responsible for constructing the Bronx Zoo. He was also a pioneering natural historical filmmaker. In the cited book, Ditmar does not mention a gleaner squirrel.

De mocking-bird de lawyer De alligator, William Cullen Bryant quotes this song heard at a corn shucking in his A Tour in the Old South, New York Evening Post (1843): De cooter is de boatman. / John John Crow. / De red-bird de soger. / John John Crow. / De mocking-bird de lawyer / John John Crow. / De alligator sawyer. / John John Crow. The song was popular; for example, Griswolds Sixth School Reader quotes it as Corn-Shucking in South Carolina (ed. Noble Butler, Kentucky: Morton & Griswold, 1857: 413). It appears in several of Bryants books and collections. night

These lines are from the chorus of a popular song, typically titled The Prairie Flower: Im a little prairie flower, / I grow wilder every hour. / Nobody cares to cultivate me, / Im as wild as I can be. The song was recorded in 1937 with claims that it was composed in that year, but it appeared in several popular sources, in various forms, beginning in 1918 and through the 1920s. The first line in MMs version is not part of the standard text.I'm not a hot house flower as you can see
I'm as wild as I can be
Nobody cares to cultivate me;
I'm wild

[Christmas card]This Christmas card, signed Mr and Mrs Jas. B. Spooner, was probably sent by people John Riddle Warner, MMs maternal grandfather, knew from his residence in Kirkwood. The text of the card, printed below an image of a house covered in snow, reads ""Hearty Greetings for Christmas / and Every Good Wish / for the Coming Year."
